History of Present Illness:
This is a 58 year old rith handed man with no significant PMH
was transfered to [**Hospital1 18**] from OSH. His wife woke up at 6 am the
day of presentation and witnessed  him jerking in the bed. He
was shaking all his limbs and was unresponsive. It lasted for
about 3 mins. He didn't bite his tongue nor did he have urinary
incontinence. He was drowsy and couldn't speak for about 30 mins
after the onset. 911 was called and he was taken to OSH . He was
given dilantin 1gm and dexamethasone 10 mg and was transfered to
[**Hospital1 18**].


Past Medical History:
None

Social History:
Lives with wife. [**Name (NI) **] delivery worker. Denies smoking and drinks
1-2 beers daily. No drugs

Family History:
Colon, lung and esophageal cancer in a few members. He had
colonoscopy 2 yrs ago and reportedly normal.

Ext: warm and well perfused.  No dark pigmented lesion and no
nodes palpable.

Neurologic examination:
Mental status: alert and oriented times 3, attentive and able to
say DOW backwards.  Follows  midline and appendicular commands.
No right left confusion, No apraxia or hemineglect. memory [**3-25**]
immediate, [**3-25**] at 10 mins. [**Location (un) 1131**] was intact. Language was
normal including naming, repetition and fluency, output.

[**Doctor First Name 81**]: Sternocleidomastoid and trapezius full strength bilaterally.

XII: Good bulk. No fasciculations. Tongue midline, movements
intact.

Normal bulk bilaterally. Tone Normal .No observed myoclonus or
tremor. No pronator drift

Radiology Report MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST Study Date of [**2123-1-29**]
6:47 PM


[**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name7 (NamePattern1) **] [**Initial (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **] FA11 [**2123-1-29**] 6:47 PM
MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST   Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 89529**]
Reason: ? neoplasm
Contrast: MAGNEVIST Amt: 19



[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
   WITH and WITHOUT CONTRAST. Concern for neoplasm on OSH CT,
first onset Sz this
   am.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
   ? neoplasm
CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR IV CONTRAST:
   None.



Provisional Findings Impression: JK [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) **] [**2123-1-29**] 8:25 PM
PFI: Solitary left frontal mass with possible small hemorrhagic
component.
Given these characteristics, either a hemorrhagic neoplasm or
potentially
metastatic, melanin-based tumor needs to be considered.


Final Report
MRI SCAN OF THE BRAIN WITH CONTRAST ENHANCEMENT

HISTORY: First onset of seizure this morning. Concern for
neoplasm.

TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted pre- and
post-gadolinium enhanced
MRI scanning of the brain was obtained.

COMPARISON STUDY ON PACS ARCHIVE: CT scan of the head performed
earlier the
same day from an outside facility.

FINDINGS: There is an avidly enhancing mass, though slightly
less intensely
enhancing within its center, sharply marginated and measuring
approximately 12
mm in diameter. It is likely intra-axial, although its most
peripheral extent
lies at the cortical surface of the left frontal lobe. There is
extensive
surrounding edema. There are no other areas of pathological
contrast
enhancement seen. There is no hydrocephalus or shift of normally
midline
structures. The mass shows slightly restricted diffusion. Within
the right
parietal lobe white matter is a 3-mm area of fluid signal
intensity which does
not exhibit pathological enhancement. Its etiology is uncertain,
although it
may represent a dilated perivascular space, as opposed to a
chronic lacunar
infarct. More typically linear perivascular spaces are seen
within the white
matter of both cerebral hemispheres, largely in a periatrial
distribution.

The mass appears to have very slight susceptibility.

The principal vascular flow patterns are identified. There is
moderate
mucosal thickening within the right maxillary sinus, and to a
minor degree in
the right mastoid sinus, consistent with an ongoing inflammatory
process.

CONCLUSION: Solitary left frontal mass with possible small
hemorrhagic
component. Given these characteristics, either a hemorrhagic
primary or
metastatic neoplasm, or potentially a metastatic, melanin-based
tumor needs to
be considered.


[**Known lastname **],[**Known firstname **] [**Medical Record Number 89528**] M  58  [**2064-5-28**]

Radiology Report CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST Study Date of
[**2123-1-30**] 3:37 PM


[**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name7 (NamePattern1) **] [**Initial (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **] FA11 [**2123-1-30**] 3:37 PM
CT CHEST W/CONTRAST; CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST   Clip #
[**Clip Number (Radiology) 89530**]
Reason: evaluate for malignancy
Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130



[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
   58 year old man with brain mass
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
   evaluate for malignancy
CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR IV CONTRAST:
   None.



Final Report
INDICATION: 58-year-old man with brain mass, to evaluate for
malignancy.

TECHNIQUE: Axial MDCT images were acquired from the thoracic
inlet to the
symphysis pubis following oral and intravenous contrast. Coronal
and sagittal
reformats were produced and reviewed. In addition, non-contrast
and
three-minute delayed post-IV contrast images were obtained
through the liver.

CT CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST:
There is an enlarged lymph node seen in the left axilla
measuring 1.6 x 2.3 x
3.3 cm. There are several smaller lymph nodes seen adjacent to
this, the
largest measures 1 cm in short axis, but has a very rounded
appearance
concerning for malignant involvement. In the left shoulder
region, lateral to
the subscapularis muscle (3:17), there is a large enhancing soft
tissue
nodule. This appears to be separate from the subscapularis
muscle measuring
4.4 x 3 x 3.2 cm. No right axillary lymphadenopathy seen. There
is also a
large left subpectoral enhancing mass seen measuring 6.4 x 5.1 x
3.3cm. There
is a small right hilar lymph node measuring 6 mm in short axis.
No other
mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes are seen. Bibasilar dependent
atelectasis
noted. There is a small area of linear scarring in the left
upper lobe. No
concerning pulmonary nodules are seen. No pleural effusions. No
pericardial
effusions. The heart and great vessels are unremarkable in
appearance.

CT ABDOMEN WITH AND WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:
No focal liver lesions are seen. The portal vein and hepatic
veins are
patent. No biliary duct dilatation seen. The gallbladder is
unremarkable in
appearance. The spleen, both adrenal glands and both kidneys are
unremarkable
in appearance. The pancreas is unremarkable in appearance. At
the splenic
hilum and in the left subdiaphragmatic space, there are several
small round
soft tissue nodules seen. These most likely represent splenules
however these
could represent small lymph nodes. There is a 1.6-cm portacaval
node seen
(2:61). There are multiple tiny paraaortic lymph nodes seen,
none of which
meet CT size criteria for pathologic enlargement. Similarly,
there are small
mesenteric lymph nodes which do not meet CT size criteria for
pathologic
enlargement. No mesenteric stranding seen. The small and large
bowel are
normal in caliber. No free fluid seen.

CT PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:
The urinary bladder, rectum and prostate are unremarkable in
appearance. No
free fluid seen. No pelvic lymphadenopathy is seen.

BONY STRUCTURES:
Mild degenerative changes noted in the lumber spine with a
gentle scoliosis
convex to the right. Sclerosis in the anterior vertebral body of
L2 may be
related to degenerative change, metastasis cannot be excluded on
this study.
Bilateral pars defects noted. Degenerative changes seen in the
left hip.

IMPRESSION:

1. Enlarged lymph nodes in the left axilla. Left shoulder soft
tissue mass
measuring 4.5 cm. Left subpectoral soft tissue mass measuring
6.4 cm. The
appearance raises suspicion most for a melanoma primary in the
left upper
extremity or shoulder area, though other tumors in this region
are possible.
Direct sampling by ultrasound guidance could be performed if
needed.

2. 1.6-cm portacaval node. Small paraaortic lymph nodes also
noted.

3. Multiple small soft tissue nodules in the left
subdiaphragmatic region are
likely splenules.

The study and the report were reviewed by the staff radiologist.

Name Birthdate    Age     Sex Pathology #     [**Hospital1 18**] [**Known lastname 89531**],[**Known firstname **]       [**2064-5-28**]    58 Male      [**Numeric Identifier 89532**] [**Numeric Identifier 89533**]

SPECIMEN SUBMITTED: LEFT AXILLARY LYMPH NODE (1 JAR)

Procedure date     Tissue received     Report Date    Diagnosed
by
[**2123-2-2**] [**2123-2-2**] [**2123-2-5**] DR. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]/dwc??????

DIAGNOSIS:

Left axillary lymph node, ultrasound-guided core biopsy:



     Metastatic malignant melanoma.





Note:

Immunohistochemical stains show that tumor cells stain positive
for S-100 protein, HMB45, MART-1 (melanA) and MITF. Cells show
weak focal staining for cytokeratin cocktail (AE1/3 and CAM
5.2). LCA (CD45) highlights background lymphocytes. The
histomorphologic and immunophenotypic findings are consistent
with metastatic malignant melanoma.

Clinical: Left axillary lymph node.
Gross:

The specimen is received in a formalin-filled container, labeled
with  the patient's  name, "[**Known lastname 3646**], [**Known firstname 449**]", and the medical
record number.  It consists of three cores of  tan-brown soft
tissue that each measure 1 cm in length x 0.1 cm in average
diameter.  The specimen is placed in histo wrap and entirely
submitted in cassette A.

[**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name3 (LF) **] J. NSURG SICU-B [**2123-2-3**] 7:26 PM
CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST   Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 89534**]
Reason: please perform at 8pm on [**2123-2-3**]; s/p left frontal
craniotom



[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
   58 year old man with sz found to have left frontal lesion,
now s/p Left frontal
   crani for excision
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
   please perform at 8pm on [**2123-2-3**]; s/p left frontal craniotomy

CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR IV CONTRAST:
   None.



Provisional Findings Impression: DLrc WED [**2123-2-3**] 8:55 PM
Status post left frontal approach craniotomy with resection of
the left
frontal mass, expected postoperative change and pneumocephalus.
No evidence
of hemorrhage or acute territorial infarction.


Final Report
INDICATION: Patient is a 58-year-old male with seizure, found to
have left
frontal mass, status post resection. Evaluate postoperative
appearance.

EXAMINATION: Non-contrast head CT.

COMPARISONS: Comparison is made to reference CT from [**2123-1-29**]
and MR
examinations from [**2123-1-29**] and [**2123-2-2**].

TECHNIQUE: Contiguous axial images were obtained through the
brain. No
intravenous contrast was administered. Coronal and sagittal
reformations are
provided for review.

FINDINGS:

The patient is status post left frontal craniotomy with expected
postoperative
changes. There is pneumocephalus seen adjacent to the craniotomy
site
extending adjacent to the left frontal lobe. There still remains

hypoattenuation centered within the left frontal lobe, most
compatible with
vasogenic edema. The previously noted mass has now been
resected. There is a
small amount of linear high-attenuation material immediately
adjacent to the
resection bed, within post-surgical limits for debris/material.
There is no
evidence of gross hemorrhage. The [**Doctor Last Name 352**]-white matter
differentiation is
preserved with no evidence of infarction. The ventricles and
sulci are
stable in size and configuration. There is no evidence of
herniation. The
visualized portions of the paranasal sinuses and mastoid air
cells are well
aerated.

IMPRESSION: Status post left frontal approach craniotomy with
resection of
the left frontal mass, with expected postoperative changes and
pneumocephalus.
No evidence of infarction orgross hemorrhage.

The study and the report were reviewed by the staff radiologist.

[**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name3 (LF) **] J. NSURG SICU-B [**2123-2-4**] 4:44 PM

Contrast: MAGNEVIST Amt: 20



[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
   58 year old man with SZ, found to have left frontal mass, now
s/p left frontal
   craniotomy for excision of mass
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
   s/p left frontal craniotomy for excision of mass
CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR IV CONTRAST:
   None.



Provisional Findings Impression: DBCd [**First Name9 (NamePattern2) **] [**2123-2-5**] 9:38 AM
The patient is status post left frontal craniotomy with excision
of the left
frontal parenchymal mass. Within the surgical bed, there are
blood products
which are intrinsically T1 hyperintense limiting evaluation for
residual
enhancing mass. The surrounding edema is slightly increased
compared with the
prior study with minimal surrounding mass effect.


Final Report
HISTORY: Status post left frontal craniotomy for excision of
left frontal
lobe mass.

TECHNIQUE: MRI of the brain was performed utilizing sagittal and
axial T1,
axial T2, axial gradient, axial FLAIR and diffusion with ADC map
sequences
without intravenous contrast. After the administration of
intravenous
contrast, axial T1 and sagittal MP-RAGE sequences were performed
with coronal
and axial MP-RAGE reconstructions.

FINDINGS: The patient is status post left frontal craniotomy and
excision of
the left frontal lobe enhancing parenchymal mass. There is
minimal scalp
swelling in the region of the left frontal craniotomy and
minimal extra-axial
fluid at the surgical site. Within the surgical bed within the
left frontal
lobe, there are blood products and surrounding edema within the
white matter
with minimal surrounding mass effect. Due to the hemorrhage
within the
surgical site, which is intrinsically T1 hyperintense,
evaluation of residual
enhancing mass in this region is limited.

The ventricles are not significantly changed in size compared
with the
pre-operative study. The major intracranial flow voids are
present. The
basal cisterns are patent.

There is mucus/fluid within the right mastoid air cells. The
paranasal
sinuses are clear. There is a stable focus of T2 hyperintensity
within the
right periventricular white matter possibly representing a
prominant
perivascular space.

IMPRESSION: The patient is status post left frontal craniotomy
with excision
of the left frontal parenchymal mass. Within the surgical bed,
there are
blood products which are intrinsically T1 hyperintense limiting
evaluation for
residual enhancing mass. The surrounding edema is slightly
increased compared
with the prior study with minimal surrounding mass effect.

The study and the report were reviewed by the staff radiologist.





Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. [**Known lastname 3646**] is a 58yo RHM with no significant PMH here after a
secondary generalized seizure.  He reports that he had a normal
colonoscopy a few years ago and recently underwent a skin biopsy
of neck lesion that was reportedly normal or basal cell.  He was
in his usual state of health when his R arm suddenly extended
followed by LOC and he was witnessed to have generalized
convulsion lasting a few minutes.  He was initially taken to an
OSH where head CT showed L frontal lesion with significant
surrounding edema hence he was transferred here for further care
after being loaded with Dilantin.

He was initially admitted to neurology service where MRI of head
with and without contrast showed an enhancing 1.2cm solitary
lesion in the L frontal lobe most concerning for melanoma.  CT
torso also showed large L axillary lymph node which was biopsied
per interventional radiology on [**2-1**].  Path report pending at
the time of discharge.

Although concerning for metastatic melanoma, given the isolated
lesion and surround edema, neuro-oncology consult (Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]
[**Last Name (NamePattern1) 724**]) recommended resection.  He was taken to OR per
neurosurgery/Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Name (STitle) **] on [**2-2**] for resection and patient
was transferred to neurosurgery after the resection.

Of note, given the concern for malignancy, Dilantin was switched
to Keppra 1g [**Hospital1 **] and he did not have any further events
concerning for seizure.  He also underwent EEG during this
admission which was normal as well.

On [**2-3**], patient was taken to the OR for L frontal craniotomy
for resection of mass. OR was uncomplicated and patient was
taken to the ICU. On post op check, a slight R drift and
expressive aphasia was noted, he was full strength otherwise. On
[**2-4**], facial twitching was observed by nursing and was relieved
with ativan. He was placed on EEG monitoring, Keppra was
increased to 1500mg [**Hospital1 **]. Patient continued to have seizures and
ativan was given. Neurology was consulted and dilantin was
added. On [**2-5**], on examination patient had RUE weakness 4/5, but
was full strenght otherwise, he was alert and oriented to self
and place and expressive aphasia persists. EEG was Dc'ed on
[**2-6**]. He remained neurologically stable.

He was seen by PT and OT and deemed safe for d/c to home with
services.  He agreed with this plan. His decadron taper will
continue over two weeks to end on 2mg po tid.

Medications on Admission:
None
